metadata.sermon_title: More Coats Than Imelda Had Shoes
metadata.sermon_start_end: John the Baptizer bursts upon the gospel of Luke. That is because it is Advent time. And whenever it is Advent time, we get John. It is not yet time for Jesus. Jesus has not yet gone public among his people. This is still time for getting ready. [...] What we know that Herod didn’t know and never even suspected, is that John’s Advent invitation cannot be silenced or arrested. It continues to invite. It addresses us in the day. It haunts us at night. And sometimes we let it come among us, and transform us.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon stays close to the structure of Luke 3. It identifies the specificity of the three groups (crowds, tax collectors, soldiers). However, it leans toward a thematic treatment of 'newness' and 'neighbor stuff' rather than uncovering what is uniquely present in this text that exists nowhere else in Scripture.
quotes: The text, from now on, is preoccupied with the question, 'What should we do?'
We are told that three 'types' came to John to put the question.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the unique 'scandal' of John's baptism in this specific Lucan context—why water and spirit are contrasted here specifically—to avoid general ethical categories.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher understands the historical roles (tax collectors as imperial agents, soldiers as enforcers), but the exegesis remains at a sociological level. There is no evidence of engagement with the original languages or the deeper theological history of Israel's expectation.
quotes: The tax collectors are jarred out of the routine by John...
The second voice is that of the tax collectors. The tax collectors are feared in that ancient society, because they had imperial money quotas to meet.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the theological weight of 'Abrahamic descent' in 1st-century Judaism more deeply than just 'pedigree' to show the radical nature of John's break with tradition.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding social justice (Imelda Marcos, redistribution of goods), but it risks becoming a general political-ethical lecture. It captures the 'zeitgeist' of consumerism well but lacks the spiritual depth Dekker demands for the 'spiritual life of the congregation.'
quotes: ...perhaps as many coats as Mrs. Marcos had shoes in Manila...
Advent is such a startling act, because it runs directly against the consumer orgy that Christmas tends to be.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'neighbor stuff' as a general category and address the specific 'misery' of the modern hearer's inability to share, rather than just the command to do so.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully avoids the 'block' method. It moves through the text and applies each section immediately. The hearer is indeed drawn into the dialogue between John and the groups.
quotes: And John, unflinching, answers them, again direct, specific, abrupt...
Now a whole lot of us are not tax collectors. But in our several ways, many of us buy and sell...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the 'present of revelation' is felt more as God speaking now, rather than just a historical figure (John) giving timeless advice.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is heavily weighted toward 'doing' (gratitude/ethics) without a sufficient foundation in 'misery' (the depth of sin) or 'redemption' (the objective work of Christ). It borders on 'works righteousness' which the preacher explicitly denies but structurally reinforces.
quotes: John is not worried here about 'works righteousness.' He says, 'Go do a few works!'
John’s stress was not only upon doing. But also quit doing.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: The 'misery' of being a 'multicoat person' needs to be framed as a state before God, not just a social inequity, to make the 'redemption' of the Holy Spirit necessary.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are present in the mention of Herod and the 'dangerous newness,' but the seriousness of being 'lost' is softened into 'missing out on newness' rather than the biblical 'destruction' or 'wrath' mentioned in the pericope (which the preacher ignores).
quotes: ...quit doing the things that keep inoculating you against God’s newness.
Herod and his company... did not want newness, so they tried to stop the dangerous newness...
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the 'ax at the root of the trees' (v. 9) which is in the text but omitted in the sermon, to restore the gravity of the choice.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the 'telos' only in a very vague sense of 'newness' or 'the coming one.' The sermon remains largely 'John-centric.' The doctrine of the two natures is absent, and Christ functions more as a symbol of a new era than the Lord who saves.
quotes: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit.
John is not the newness. He preps us for the newness.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Explicitly link the 'doing' to the 'One who is more powerful' (v. 16). Grace must be the source of the ability to share, not just the result of it.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1350 words, the sermon likely lasts 13-14 minutes. According to Dekker's Thesis 8, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for 'depth.'
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the theological exposition of the Holy Spirit and the person of Christ to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s criteria primarily in its brevity and its shift toward ethical horizontalism. It neglects the 'misery' and 'wrath' present in the text, replacing the 'two ways' with a choice between 'old routines' and 'newness.' While it is concrete and avoids generalities, it functions more as a social-ethical call to action than a form of the Word of God where Christ is the telos.
strengths: Concrete application: The use of the 'Imelda Marcos' imagery and the specific address to 'money managers' and 'enforcers' avoids the 'general truth' prohibition.
Interwoven structure: The preacher successfully mixes exposition of the Lucan types with contemporary equivalents.
weaknesses: Insufficient length: At ~14 minutes, it lacks the 'breadth' Dekker demands for substantive preaching.
Weak Christology: Christ is an abstract 'newness' rather than the incarnate Lord; the 'redemption' part of the 3-2-1 rule is underdeveloped.
Avoidance of Judgment: By ignoring the 'unquenchable fire' and 'ax' in the passage, the preacher softens the 'two ways' into a psychological or social preference.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate ethical speech, but it is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker’s definition. It lacks the required duration for depth, the necessary Trinitarian background (misery/redemption), and the sharp focus on Christ as the specific telos of the text.
